**Feedback & Actionable Edits**  
Your draft sketches a plausible macro‑to‑firm link but falls short of a world‑class, multi‑year structural thesis. 1) **Causal chain & first‑principles**: Explicitly map how the *real‑rate differential* (Fed rate hikes → dollar appreciation → higher capital costs) and *terms‑of‑trade* (tariff escalation on battery cells) feed into Rivian’s cost structure, margin compression, and the R2 launch decision. 2) **Quantify every anchor**: Cite the exact tariff rate (e.g., 25 % on battery cells, ID 4LQD15CFU), the $7,500 credit removal date, and the projected R2 volume (e.g., 30 % higher than R1, ID JVKCZAPVG). 3) **Regime transition**: Define the “low‑growth” regime (e.g., real GDP growth < 1 %) and the “high‑growth” regime (e.g., > 3 %) and show the threshold where Rivian’s EBITDA breakeven (2027) becomes attainable. 4) **Layoff channel**: Tie IBM’s 26,000‑role cut (10 % of workforce, ID 4LQD15CFU) to a broader productivity shock metric (e.g., total factor productivity decline of 0.5 pp). 5) **Coverage & citations**: Add at least one citation per key claim (e.g., “Rivian’s gross margin target 15 %” → ID JVKCZAPVG; “Fed rate path 5 % by 2026” → ID 4LQD15CFU). 6) **Risk & watch list**: Expand risks to include “tariff escalation > 30 %”, “EV credit removal without replacement”, and “AI‑driven layoffs > 5 % of workforce” with corresponding IDs. 7) **Confidence framing**: Quantify confidence (e.g., “moderate‑high (70 %)”) and link it to the strength of the cash buffer (ID JVKCZAPVG). 8) **Structure**: Re‑order paragraphs to first present the macro anchors, then the firm‑level response, then the layoff channel, and finally the base case & risks. 9) **Avoid generic language**: Replace “tend to compress margins” with “margin compression of ~3 pp observed in Q2 2025 (ID JVKCZAPVG)”. 10) **Reconcile conflicts**: If any source contradicts (e.g., Tesla’s gross margin vs. Rivian’s), explicitly note the divergence and explain the basis for preference. Implement these edits to elevate depth, clarity, and first‑principles rigor.
